result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Attorney Eryn Menden
Hearing on May 31, 2022 at 10:00 am.

Defendant to have no contact with Victim A listed in the Criminal Complaint/Victim Identification Key, unless the defendant is working for Victim A.  Defendant is not to share, reproduce or distribute any personal and/or identifying information about the crime victim(s), except to their attorney.

09:11 AM Defendant Darryl Francis Schaefer in court.  Andrew Nesheim appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defense acknowledges receipt of complaint and waives reading of complaint.  Service admitted/advised of charges and potential penalties.  Court advises of right to an attorney.  Defendant is eligible for State Public Defender representation.  An attorney will be appointed.  The State indicates they have been in compliance with victims rights and notified them this case would be moved to today's date.  Court informs the State to let the victims know the initial appearance set for May 26 will no longer be on the calendar.  Court tolled time limits for preliminary hearing.  Hearing scheduled for May 31, 2022 at 10:00 am.
